And They Say He Lacks Dimension
We are each -- if you will permit us a moment of philosophy -- the star of our own cartoon show, but we cannot help wondering if BOB EVANS isn't going to get himself sued.

''Kid Notorious'' makes its debut on Comedy Central next Wednesday night. The animated characters are often real people and Mr. Evans provides his own voice. The first episode involves a fictional fight with SHARON STONE, who dumps an Evans project to go to New York and star in ''The Vagina Monologues.''
''Someone put it into her head she can act,'' Mr. Evans says in the show, in one of his nicer, and cleaner, lines.
Mr. Evans and Ms. Stone had their problems a decade ago when he was producing the thriller ''Sliver.'' She had him banned from the set; he later called her a ''sociopath.''
What gives with them now, we asked at a press lunch yesterday at Michael's.
''Nothing,'' Mr. Evans said.
Then, ''We've had a very bad experience in the past'' and ''Let's say it this way: she doesn't like me.''
So is the cartoon a way to settle scores?
''It wasn't done out of spite; in the end it may help her.''
Is he worried about hearing from her lawyer?
''I couldn't care less. Couldn't care less.'' An impish smile. ''Hope I do.''
Mr. Evans, as the Hollywood producer Kid Notorious, wears a turtleneck, cashmere suit and silver bolo, and can say ''Baby, you take my breath away'' in 67 languages.

Mr. Evans, in three dimensions, is similar. At 73, his hair is still thick and dark, his complexion deeply tan, the color of each suspect. Since having had a stroke a few years ago, he walks a little gingerly, but the ladies' man charm is fully operational. ''Put me between a blonde and a brunette,'' he said, as he arrived.
We were distracted by his small rectangular very blue tinted glasses. Mr. Evans told us he had designed them for the Notorious character.
The bolo?

''That's all I wear,'' he said. ''I saw a belly dancer eight years ago. She had this on her belly and I loved it.'' Being a deal maker, Mr. Evans offered $100, a week later $300 and, finally, $1,000. ''It's the cheapest thing I ever bought,'' he said.
The belly dancer's name was PERLA and she later became the wife of SLASH, of Guns N' Roses. Slash, who supplies his own voice, is also a character in ''Kid Notorious.''
We hear, Mr. Evans, that you've crossed paths with PARIS HILTON?
''Nice girl,'' Mr. Evans says. ''Funny girl. I don't know her that well.''
She's been known to misbehave.
''Nothing wrong with misbehaving. It all depends on how you misbehave. See, I can't misbehave in public. I never have. I'm a very, very reclusive person.''
And if You Saw a Pictorial Of Sing Sing
Condé Nast Traveler held its Readers' Choice Awards event at the Guggenheim the other day.
In the crowd were CINDY CRAWFORD, RANDE GERBER, CHRIS NOTH, VENDELA, MARISKA HARGITAY and REBECCA ROMIJN STAMOS.

Ms. Romijn Stamos, a Sports Illustrated swimsuit model, was wearing a low-cut black and white striped dress only somewhat less snug than the body paint she wore in her ''X-Men'' movies but our Sartorial Splendor award must go to the Giants linebacker DHANI JONES.
Mr. Jones wore blue flip-flops with his beige suit, gold bow tie and powder blue shirt.
''Dhani has been trying to get a writing assignment from me since I met him a couple of years ago,'' said TOM WALLACE, the magazine's editor.

Elsewhere -- no, dang it, you're too linguistically sophisticated a readership not to see through that tired journalistic segue -- in remarks having nothing at all to do with Mr. Jones's flip-flops -- LIEV SCHREIBER, who has just finished shooting a remake of ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' told us of a vacation he had impulsively booked in Brazil. (He had seen a ''gorgeous'' photograph in the magazine.)

''There was kayaking, hiking, a very sporty guy trip,'' Mr. Schreiber said. ''So I just booked it. Then I got there and it turned out I had booked myself into an eight-day detox weight-loss spiritual-growth center. And I was the only man. It actually turned out to be a terrific vacation.''
